description:
Rhizobium ruizarguesonis is a species of nitrogen-fixing bacteria that forms symbiotic relationships with leguminous plants. It was first isolated from the root nodules of the legume Lupinus angustifolius (narrow-leaved lupine) growing in the Ruiz Argueso region of Spain.

Rhizobium ruizarguesonis is a Gram-negative, aerobic, non-spore-forming, motile bacterium. It is a slow-growing species, with colonies typically appearing within 5-7 days on yeast extract-mannitol agar. The cells are rod-shaped and measure approximately 0.5-0.8 μm in width and 1.2-2.0 μm in length.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that R. ruizarguesonis belongs to the genus Rhizobium and is most closely related to other Rhizobium species that nodulate lupins and other legumes. The species is able to fix atmospheric nitrogen and provide this essential nutrient to the host plant in exchange for carbohydrates produced through photosynthesis.

Understanding the diversity and ecology of Rhizobium species, such as R. ruizarguesonis, is important for developing effective inoculants for sustainable agricultural practices involving legume cultivation.
